headline: Trump rips new Kavanaugh claim
subHeadline: Book alleges second exposure incident at party.

utterances.speaker: HOWARD KURTZ, HOST
utterances.sentences: Breaking news on the Buzz Meter this Sunday: Two New York Times reporters say there was a second alleged incident of Brett Kavanaugh exposing himself at a drunken college party but without interviewing the source making the claim. President Trump calls the new account lies and says the Supreme Court justice should sue for libel. utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.sentences: Was the press right all along about the former Fox News contributor being increasingly sidelined in the White House? I'm Howard Kurtz and this is "Media Buzz." This is a Fox News alert. The New York Times began by deleting a tasteless tweet about a book essay by two of its reporters on the Brett Kavanaugh nomination fight. It's an odd opinion section piece that waits until the ninth paragraph to describe what's called new information about the allegations by Deborah Ramirez. She is the woman who took six days to assess her memories before telling The New Yorker that Kavanaugh exposed himself to her at a party at Yale, which he has flatly denied. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('mobile', 'ban7', 'mobile-mw-ad-ban7', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } The Times's authors in their book say they spoke to seven people who heard about the alleged incident many years ago, and they published a second allegation about another drunken dorm party at Yale where Kavanaugh supposedly pulled down his pants and friends pushed a woman into touching him. And yet reporters didn't talk to the former classmate, Max Stier, who is claiming that this happened, but to two officials who communicated with him. President Trump tweeted about the story this morning. "Now, the radical left Democrats and their partner, the lamestream media, are after Brett Kavanaugh again, talking loudly of their favorite word, impeachment. He is an innocent man who has been treated horribly. Such lies about him. They want to scare him into turning liberal." And the president said, "Brett Kavanaugh should start suing people for libel, or the Justice Department should come to his rescue." if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('tablet', 'lb7', 'tablet-tw-ad-lb7', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } Joining us now to analyze the coverage of this and other issues: Ben Domenech, founder and publisher of The Federalist; Susan Ferrechio, chief congressional correspondent of The Washington Examiner; and Jeanne Zaino, professor of media and government at Iona College. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('mobile', 'ban8', 'mobile-mw-ad-ban8', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } Ben, we haven't read the book, but is it fair for The New York Times to have the reporters, Robin Pogrebin and Kate Kelly, drop this into an analysis piece, a charge of this magnitude against a sitting Supreme Court justice without the backup that ordinarily is required of a hard news story?

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.sentences: And joining us now from Los Angeles, Sean Spicer, the former White House press secretary and senior advisor to the America First PAC. Sean, welcome.

utterances.sentences: Good morning.

utterances.sentences: We were talking a few moments ago about -- good morning to you. We were talking a few moments ago about John Bolton being kind of pushed out of the White House. After Bolton and Jim Mattis and Rex Tillerson and many others, the media verdict seems to be that the president eventually loses patience with almost everyone who works with him. Your thoughts? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.sentences: I think in this case it's a little bit different. I think, obviously, Ambassador Bolton has served this country well. And there's clearly right now a divide between what Ambassador Bolton thought was the correct foreign policy particularly with respect to Syria and other Libyan or hot spots. But Secretary Pompeo and the president think otherwise and I think the president clearly deserves to have people around him that agree with his foreign-policy. They may challenge him and bring up other ideas --

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.sentences: -- but don't fundamentally have a different way of thinking.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.sentences: Right. Now the Washington Post analysis of this is that the president sometimes has a Kafkaesque management style which he doesn't want his appointee to get bad press but he doesn't want them to get too much good press and he demands absolute fealty in the words of this article.

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.sentences: Well, again, this is more of a policy thing than anything else. I don't think that John Bolton was on the cover of too many magazines or out in front of it. And the president deserves to have people around him that understand his agenda and are ready to implement and not go in a different direction. It's one thing to challenge him to challenge him and bring up new ideas, it's another thing to not follow through in the direction once the president hears you out and makes a decision.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.sentences: Right. Let's turn to the breaking news. utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.sentences: Well, and they didn't talk to Kavanaugh either. So that's a big --

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.sentences: But they did -- they did asked -- they did asked to speak to Kavanaugh and he declined.

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.sentences: But your thoughts on whether the story should have been published.

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.sentences: Correct. But there are two sources in this. One that clearly know. One is Kavanaugh, one is Ms. Ramirez. Neither one of them spoke to the Times. But the idea that there is not outrage on the left. Where's Kirsten Gillibrand? Where is Hillary Clinton? The idea that they used the language that they did and I will not repeat it here on television, in that tweet and there's no outrage from these people who have stood up and talked about fighting for women and all of these inappropriate remarks is disgusting. The idea that other colleagues at the New York Times who sit there and watch this happen aren't speaking out and saying this is not acceptable at the times. Time and time again the New York Times has a pattern of doing inappropriate things. Last week, we saw the political editor reveal all of these anti- Semitic tweets and everyone at the New York Times that sits there and lets it goes by is complicit. So, for all the talk about what Donald Trump says and does that coming from the New York Times they need to mind their own house first. They've got a problem with anti-Semitic comments from their own staff. This was clearly a highly inappropriate tweet that was put out.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.sentences: Right. Here's to --

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.sentences: Another example of the folks online doing stuff and the idea that everyone washes it away. The New York Times has a serious problem. And the idea that every one of those journalists that work there, their other colleagues and these folks on the left that claim to have this holier than thou attitude are silent just shows you the hypocrisy that goes on right now.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.sentences: Let me jump in and clarify. The Times did delete the tweet. It began with, essentially a woman being confronted --

utterances.speaker: SPICER
utterances.sentences: Right. And by the way they said it was -- whoa, whoa, whoa, hold on, Howie.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.sentences: Sean, let me finish. Sean, let me finish.

utterances.speaker: SPICER

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: SPICER

utterances.speaker: KURTZ

utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ

utterances.sentences: They want to excuse everybody that supports this president but as long as you're lying to go against the president for this greater good that they're brought in on that's OK.
